awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Energy harvesting platform for tire monitoring and communication
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve prediction of vehicle tire failure and enable systems for vehicle preventative maintenance. The proposed technology may be used to power smart vehicle tire sensors that will give alerts for tire maintenance and replacement. This technology will improve the functionality of the current tire pressure monitoring systems and improve the safety of automobile travel.  Each year in the U.S. there are tens of thousands of motor vehicle crashes due to tire failures.  Tire failure is also responsible for a significant portion of roadside emergencies which also cause financial loss, time delay, and safety concerns.  The proposed technology may help address these problems and enable improved tire failure prediction which is not possible in conventional tire pressure monitoring systems.

This I-Corps project develops a flexible nanowire-based piezoelectric energy harvester that can effectively convert the mechanical vibration or strain of a vehicle tire into electric power.  The system can retain the piezo-electric properties even at the high operating temperatures experienced by the tire.  As a result, the batteryless energizer can be used to power evolving families of smart tire sensors that can monitor various vehicle and road conditions. By functioning as a stable energy source with improved power budget compared to many battery-based solutions, the proposed energy harvesting platform may provide more flexibility and support advanced tire sensing features.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Each year, more than 220 million flat tires occur in the U.S., which leads to more than 78,000 motor vehicle crashes that cause more than 700 deaths. This ends up as $19 billion of financial loss due to lawsuit and repair cost. Aside from the mechanical failures, about 26% of the roadside emergencies are due to flat tires that cause loss of money and time. But, the current tire pressure monitoring system (TPMS) cannot predict tire failures ahead of time. As a result, there is an emerging need for smart tire sensor technology that can predict tire failure and alter the driver for preventative maintenance. The goal of this project is to build a business model for our piezoelectric energy harvester that can power smart tire sensors through market analysis, customer interviews, and technology development.

Based on our market analysis results, the global intelligent tire and sensor market has shown steady growth and is expecting to reach total revenue of $77.51 billion by 2024 with annual growth rate of 7.44%. In particular, the U.S. held the largest market share of 22.45% in 2018. Owing to the increasing demand for cost-effective tire maintenance and increased vehicle data for connected vehicles, there has been a significant amount of R&D investments to develop intelligent and smart tires at present.   

Throughout the I-Corps program, our team interviewed more than 100 customers including individual car owners, tire/auto manufacturers, fleet services, and autonomous vehicle design groups. Based on the interviews, tire manufacturers are interested, since they think their customers can benefit from this technology. Individual car owners think that this technology can get rid of the guessing for when to replace the tire. However, not all the individuals were positive. The people who were positive considered safety as the top priority. Fleet service are most likely to pay the highest cost, since daily monitoring the tire condition is cumbersome, and often mis-performed can lead to loss of money and time. We also identified the fleet service as our target market, since they will mostly benefit from our technology. Furthermore, as part of the business model development, we have identified three business partners – Bridgestone, Goodyear, and ArcBest Fleet. Our team continued to find customers for our technology and work on technology development. For customer development, we found a local tire company – American Triangle Tire Technology (A3T LLC) that showed interest in our piezoelectric energy harvester. There have been multiple meetings with A3T regarding collaboration on the piezoelectric energy harvester development and testing.

On the technology side, to realize the piezoelectric energy harvester, Nylon-11 nanowires are synthesized on flexible polycarbonate terephthalate (PCET) and polyethylene terephthalate (PETE) substrates using template wetting method. Furthermore, the material characteristics of the nanowire are evaluated with SEM and XRD analysis. Following the SEM and XRD analysis, the electrical characterization of the nanowire filled templates was evaluated via capacitance-voltage (CV) sweep. For this test, electrodes were created using nickel conductive paint coating (MG Chemicals 841AR) on the top and bottom surfaces of the template. The capacitance was characterized as a function of direct current (DC) voltage bias, where the nanowire template was connected to a probe station (Signatone 1160 Series Probe Station) which was used as the inputs to the characterization system (Keithley Semiconductor Characterization System Model 4200-SCS) responsible for the capacitance measurements. The results showed existence of the hysteresis loop that implies the nanowire template is exhibiting ferroelectric properties which is desirable for piezoelectric energy harvesters.

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2023
Modified by: Kye-Shin Lee
